Award.AwardTitle: James Madison University EPIC (Expanding Pathways, Identity and Capacity) Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
James Madison University's EPIC (Expanding Pathways, Identity and Capacity (EPIC) for Preparing Science Teachers) project, a Capacity Building project funded through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, addresses the demand for highly qualified secondary science teachers by creating new, more flexible pathways for STEM undergraduates to pursue teaching careers. The project will (i) build institutional capacity by creating additional curricular on-ramps for the science teacher education program leading to licensure; (ii) offer experiences that explicitly develop pedagogical content knowledge early in the undergraduate career; (iii) recruit, retain, and mentor a community of preservice teachers engaged in early teaching experiences that build their identity as secondary science teachers; and (iv) increase the number of students participating in the preservice teaching curriculum as well as informal teaching experiences. In the long term, the project will lead to an expanded pool of well-trained MAT candidates who will be prepared to enter the workforce as secondary science teachers.

A team of faculty members representing the College of Education and the four science disciplines (Biology, Chemistry, Earth science/Geology, and Physics) housed within the College of Science and Math, with the support of the Administration, will develop two additional credit-bearing pathways leading to science teacher licensure that supplement the existing program at James Madison University. Instruction will focus on science-specific pedagogical content knowledge developed through early teaching experiences, courses targeted at science secondary education students, and mentoring by instructional coaching teams consisting of both a science content and pedagogy expert. Additional elements include active recruiting of potential teacher candidates, targeted advising within the science disciplines, establishing a freshman learning community, offering summer teaching opportunities, and building community across the 5-year BA/BS/MAT program through an active National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) student chapter. Through these efforts to provide early teaching experiences, community building, and additional curricular pathways incorporating mentoring by coaching teams, the investigators aim to understand the role that these experiences play in the development of science teacher identity, demonstrating pedagogical competencies, the construction of pedagogical content knowledge of secondary science education students, and their persistence in a rigorous program of professional preparation. By assessing outcomes for populations following each distinct track, the role of these varied experiences in teacher preparation both in developing pedagogical content knowledge and producing critical incidents leading to science teacher identity will be characterized. Data will include qualitative and quantitative analysis based on individual case studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-supported Noyce Capacity Building project, EPIC (Expanding Pathways, Identity and Capacity) Science Education grew out of a need to increase the number of James Madison University (JMU) science graduates who chose to pursue science teaching as a career. This project was a collaboration among faculty in Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, Secondary Education, and Physics, all of whom who are involved in teacher preparation.  

The goals of the project were to (1) build institutional support by creating additional pathways to pursue licensure; (2) offer early-career experiences that help students develop an interest and expertise in science teaching; (3) recruit, retain, and mentor preservice teachers to help them identify as secondary science teachers and (4) increase the number of science students participating in preservice teacher activities leading to earning licensure.  

To create additional pathways to pursue licensure (Goal 1), we experimented with alternate routes to enter the science teacher licensure program at JMU, which consists of the completion of an undergraduate major in a science discipline, a secondary education minor, and a Master of Arts in Teaching degree. The sustainable solution, and the one that offered students the greatest flexibility, was to split the first block of science education courses so that students could take them together or spread across several semesters. This was aided by the development of a general secondary teaching methods class specific to science majors. This course also helped these students to develop their personal identities as science educators along with their identities as scientists (Goal 3).

We increased the number of students in the preservice teacher pipeline (Goal 2) by introducing early-career teaching opportunities and participating in recruiting events. In addition to introducing 94 potential pre-service teachers to early science teaching experiences, hundreds of K-12 students were impacted by after school science clubs at local middle schools, summer enrichment camps for middle and secondary students, and group demonstrations lead by EPIC participants. We were able to attract students to these programs (Goal 3) by offering a choice of credit hours or a modest stipend for participation. We shared the program offerings with pre-college students through open-houses, directing undergraduate scholarships to prospective students interested in science teaching, and targeted recruiting through high school science teachers. We also reached of current students through general recruiting and “Get the Facts Out” campaigns.

A key element to our strategies was to develop a strong community of science educators with a strong identity (Goal 3). Differentiated science coursework, reactivating JMU’s chapter of the National Science Teacher Association, and interaction with current educators through the Virginia Association of Science Teachers were important in building this community and identity.

Over the period of this grant, we have introduced 94 students to early-career teaching experiences and had 34 students earn licensure to teach science. Fifteen percent of students earning licensure did so through alternate pathways introduced by this program; without these alternate routes, these students would not have been able to enter the secondary education minor and earn teaching licensure.  The project team shared our results through 10 presentations and 1 publication, and this program had a direct impact on other work in science teacher preparation at JMU.

EPIC was focused on science teacher preparation, but elements of the program are being considered by other areas of secondary education to help increase the number of preservice teachers in general at JMU. The program elements that have been institutionalized led directly to the development of a successfully funded Track 1 Scholarship proposal, which is designed to include science, mathematics and engineering teacher candidates.
